It would be interesting if someone were to implement supervisor networks si=
miliar to the STANNOs patented by Dr. Thaler.

  ----- Original Message ---=
-- 
  From: afcarl2 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, October=
 18, 2006 7:23 PM
  Subject: [neat] Supervisor NEAT


  The benefit of inco=
rporating a neat supervisor goes beyond simple 
  manipulation of parameter=
s. To maximize the benefits associated with 
  those demonstrated in the FS=
NEAT paper, requires that 
  multiple "Initial Populations" be evaluated to=
 identify the most 
  beneficial portion of the input feature space, which =
also represents 
  the most effective expenditure of computational resource=
s. The below 
  sample problem demonstrates the effect of effectively varyi=
ng the 
  population in a non-linear fashion verses generations of evolutio=
n, 
  while keeping the parameters constant. It is likely that the 
  param=
eters can be advantageously manipulated to accelerate this 
  process. Whil=
e computational time is not recorded, the associated CPU 
  time correspond=
ing to increasing number of generations is profoundly 
  higher, even for t=
he constant product of (# Initial Populations)x(# 
  Generations of Evoluti=
on), which is just another way of saying that 
  the more complex genomes e=
volved with increasing number of 
  generations of evolution take dispropor=
tionately longer to evaluate.

  Type Problem: Data Representation

  # Inp=
uts =3D (3) + (1) Bias
  # Outputs =3D (1)
  # Samples =3D (4)
  Parameters=
 =3D Held Constant, same as "pole2_markov.ne"

  Minimal Starter Gene w/ on=
ly (1) connection from Bias to Output

  "A" =3D # Initial Populations
  "B=
" =3D # Generations
  "C" =3D Average Overall Highest Fitness (i.e. across =
all Initial 
  Populations)
  "D" =3D Maximum Overall Highest Fitness (i.e.=
 across all Initial 
  Populations)
  "E" =3D Minimum Overall Highest Fitne=
ss (i.e. across all Initial 
  Populations)

  "A" "B" "C" "D" "E"
